sections.title: H.C.F. (Highest Common Factor)
content: The H.C.F. of two or more than two numbers is the greatest number that divides each of them exactly.
There are two methods to find HCF:

subsections.title: Factorization Method
subsections.description: Express each number as a product of prime factors. The product of the common factors gives the HCF.

subsections.title: Division Method
subsections.description: Divide the larger number by the smaller. Continue dividing previous divisor by remainder until remainder is zero. The last divisor is the HCF.

subsections.title: Finding HCF of more than two numbers
subsections.description: Find HCF of any two numbers first, then with the third, and so on.
subsections.example: Find HCF of 20, 36, 100 → HCF(20, 36) = 4; HCF(4, 100) = 4 → Final HCF = 4

sections.title: L.C.M. (Least Common Multiple)
content: The least number divisible by all the given numbers is called their LCM.
Use factorization with common multiples. LCM is the product of all factors.
sections.note: If the greatest number is a multiple of all others, that number is the LCM. Example: LCM of 24, 4, 8 → 24

sections.title: Useful Properties
content: Product of two numbers = Product of their H.C.F. and L.C.M.
Co-prime Numbers: Two numbers are co-prime if their HCF = 1
If one number is a multiple of another → HCF = smaller number, LCM = larger number

sections.title: HCF and LCM of Fractions
content: HCF of Fraction = HCF of Numerators / LCM of Denominators
LCM of Fraction = LCM of Numerators / HCF of Denominators

sections.title: Remainder Based Problems
content: If X is remainder when N is divided by x, y, z then: N = K × LCM(x, y, z) + X
If A, B, C are remainders and x − A = y − B = z − C = P then: N = K × LCM(x, y, z) − P
